channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Forecast warns when sea life will get tangled in nets — a year in advance
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03870-1

Computational model uses sea-surface temperatures to predict when whales and turtles are likely to get stuck in fishing gear.
item.dc:title: Forecast warns when sea life will get tangled in nets — a year in advance
item.dc:creator: Carissa Wong

Broaden scope of review boards to boost public trust

item.title: Brain implants help people to recover after severe head injury
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02833-w

Electrodes placed inside the brains of five people with traumatic injuries improved their performance in attention and memory tests.
item.dc:title: Brain implants help people to recover after severe head injury
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.title: Is AI leading to a reproducibility crisis in science?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03817-6

Scientists worry that ill-informed use of artificial intelligence is driving a deluge of unreliable or useless research.
item.dc:title: Is AI leading to a reproducibility crisis in science?
item.dc:creator: Philip Ball

item.title: Climate researchers need support to become scientist-communicators
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03436-1

Scientific institutions must create roles so that researchers can provide the deep public engagement necessary to respond effectively to the escalating impacts of climate change.
item.dc:title: Climate researchers need support to become scientist-communicators
item.dc:creator: Daniel Swain

item.title: Combat corporate greenwashing with better science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03815-8

Companies must be transparent about how they calculate their emissions goals. Researchers must help to clear up doubts about the system.
item.dc:title: Combat corporate greenwashing with better science

item.title: Most scientists don’t enjoy writing grants. Here’s how to change that
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03871-0

Specialists share how to make the experience more enjoyable and foster a sense of belonging.
item.dc:title: Most scientists don’t enjoy writing grants. Here’s how to change that
item.dc:creator: Courtney Peña
Amber R. Moore
Crystal M. Botham

item.title: Scientists skip COP28 to demand climate action at home
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03829-2

Concerned about safety at the global climate summit and wanting to make their protests count, researchers stage demonstrations elsewhere.
item.dc:title: Scientists skip COP28 to demand climate action at home
item.dc:creator: Anil Oza

item.title: How hyenas decide whether to form a lion-fighting mob
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03778-w

Monitoring complex hyena societies in the wild sheds light on factors that predict whether individuals will engage in a risky collective activity.
item.dc:title: How hyenas decide whether to form a lion-fighting mob
item.dc:creator: Mary Abraham

item.title: Earliest known fossil mosquito is a blood-sucking surprise
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03757-1

Insects trapped in amber reveal that male mosquitoes, too, could once extract blood.
item.dc:title: Earliest known fossil mosquito is a blood-sucking surprise

item.title: Hard data: looking deep into Indigenous forests
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03820-x

Louis De Grandpré studies the traditional lands of Canada’s Pessamit people in the face of widespread logging.
item.dc:title: Hard data: looking deep into Indigenous forests
item.dc:creator: Nicola Jones

item.title: A low-cost electron microscope maps proteins at speed
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03748-2

Bespoke cryo-electron microscope reveals 3D details of cellular structures — and is an order of magnitude cheaper than its rivals.
item.dc:title: A low-cost electron microscope maps proteins at speed

item.title: IBM releases first-ever 1,000-qubit quantum chip
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03854-1

The company announces its latest huge chip — but will now focus on developing smaller chips with a fresh approach to ‘error correction’.
item.dc:title: IBM releases first-ever 1,000-qubit quantum chip
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Genetic risk converges on regulatory networks mediating early type 2 diabetes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06693-2

Integration of multiomics data with functional analysis of pancreatic tissues from individuals with early-stage type 2 diabetes indicates that the genetic risk converges on RFX6, which regulates chromatin architecture at multiple risk loci.
item.dc:title: Genetic risk converges on regulatory networks mediating early type 2 diabetes

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03853-2

item.title: Daily briefing: Biosensor ring detects sex hormone in sweat
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03868-9

A prototype biosensor that is worn as a ring can detect tiny amounts of oestradiol in sweat. Plus, colliding black holes ring like bells and dolphins can sense electricity.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Biosensor ring detects sex hormone in sweat
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.content:encoded:

Tumours respond more readily to radiation and other therapies in mice without a specific protein in their dendritic cells.

item.title: Daily briefing: A historic moment for loss and damage at COP28
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03850-5

COP28 started with the first cash pledged for countries devastated by climate change. Plus, penguins survive on thousands of microsleeps and how to finally end the HIV/AIDS pandemic.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: A historic moment for loss and damage at COP28
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: How to create compelling scientific data visualisations
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03393-9

Start with pen and paper, keep things simple, do your coding at the end, say data visualisation specialists.
item.dc:title: How to create compelling scientific data visualisations
item.dc:creator: Julie Gould

item.title: Approaching 1.5 °C: how will we know we’ve reached this crucial warming mark?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03775-z

Assessing global mean temperature rise using the average warming over the previous one or two decades will delay formal recognition of when Earth breaches the Paris agreement’s 1.5 °C guard rail. Here is what’s needed to avoid the wait.
item.dc:title: Approaching 1.5 °C: how will we know we’ve reached this crucial warming mark?
item.dc:creator: Richard A. Betts

An accidental meeting.
item.dc:title: Endlings
item.dc:creator: Giancarla Espinosa Aritao

item.title: Climate change is also a health crisis — these 3 graphics explain why
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03804-x

Health is on the agenda at the COP28 climate meeting. Rising temperatures increase the spread of infectious diseases, claim lives and drive food insecurity.
item.dc:title: Climate change is also a health crisis — these 3 graphics explain why
item.dc:creator: Carissa Wong

item.title: Evelyn Fox Keller (1936–2023), philosopher who questioned gender roles in science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03819-4

Mathematical biologist, philosopher and historian of science who challenged the vision of science as a masculine activity.
item.dc:title: Evelyn Fox Keller (1936–2023), philosopher who questioned gender roles in science
item.dc:creator: Marga Vicedo

item.title: The hunt for dark-matter particles ventures into the wild
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03749-1

Sensors deployed at magnetically quiet rural sites looked for axions and ‘hidden photons’ — with no luck yet.
item.dc:title: The hunt for dark-matter particles ventures into the wild

item.title: Tiny robots made from human cells heal damaged tissue
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03777-x

The ‘anthrobots’ were able to repair a scratch in a layer of neurons in the lab.
item.dc:title: Tiny robots made from human cells heal damaged tissue
item.dc:creator: Matthew Hutson

item.title: This penguin survives on 4-second microsleeps — thousands of times a day
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03751-7

The power naps of the chinstrap penguin are even briefer and more frequent when it is tending eggs.
item.dc:title: This penguin survives on 4-second microsleeps — thousands of times a day
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: Dolphins have a feel for electric fields
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03750-8

The bottlenose dolphin’s keen ‘electroreception’ sense might help it to locate buried prey and navigate the seas.
item.dc:title: Dolphins have a feel for electric fields

item.title: Sanitary products made from plants could help tackle period poverty
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03802-z

Researchers have extracted absorbent materials from the succulent Agave sisalana for making local, low-cost period products.
item.dc:title: Sanitary products made from plants could help tackle period poverty
item.dc:creator: Julie Gould

item.title: Wearable biosensor measures fertility hormones in sweat
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03812-x

Ring-like device blends nanoelectronics and folded RNA to track hormone levels without the need for invasive blood tests.
item.dc:title: Wearable biosensor measures fertility hormones in sweat
item.dc:creator: Amanda Heidt

item.title: World’s biggest set of human genome sequences opens to scientists
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03763-3

The whole genomes of 500,000 people in the UK Biobank will help researchers to probe our genetic code for links to disease.
item.dc:title: World’s biggest set of human genome sequences opens to scientists
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: Generative AI could revolutionize health care — but not if control is ceded to big tech
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03803-y

Large language models such as that used by ChatGPT could soon become essential tools for diagnosing and treating patients. To protect people’s privacy and safety, medical professionals, not commercial interests, must drive their development and deployment.
item.dc:title: Generative AI could revolutionize health care — but not if control is ceded to big tech
item.dc:creator: Augustin Toma
Senthujan Senkaiahliyan
Patrick R. Lawler
Barry Rubin
Bo Wang

item.title: Daily briefing: Super hot plasma made easy with stabilizing fibres
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03827-4

Carbon fibres help to create a stable plasma with a uniform temperature. Plus, a soft robotic tentacle inspired by octopuses and materials called perovskites could help solar panels to deliver 20% more power.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Super hot plasma made easy with stabilizing fibres
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Microbiologists at COP28 push for a seat at the climate-policy table
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03765-1

At this week’s big climate summit and beyond, scientists are campaigning for microbes to be included in climate models and solutions.
item.dc:title: Microbiologists at COP28 push for a seat at the climate-policy table
item.dc:creator: Katherine Bourzac

item.title: First cash pledged for countries devastated by climate change: COP28 starts with historic decision
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03814-9

Draft resolution on a ‘loss and damage fund’ has attracted more than $400 million, but climate-vulnerable countries say more cash is needed.
item.dc:title: First cash pledged for countries devastated by climate change: COP28 starts with historic decision
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson

item.title: ChatGPT one year on: who is using it, how and why?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03798-6

In just a year, ChatGPT has permeated scientific research. Seven scientists reveal what they have learnt about how the chatbot should — and shouldn’t — be used.
item.dc:title: ChatGPT one year on: who is using it, how and why?
item.dc:creator: Marzyeh Ghassemi
Abeba Birhane
Mushtaq Bilal
Siddharth Kankaria

Francisco Tustumi

item.title: Why COP28 probably won’t keep the 1.5 degree dream alive
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03773-1

We discuss the challenges of the upcoming climate-change conference, and a way to make stable plasma using hairy blocks.
item.dc:title: Why COP28 probably won’t keep the 1.5 degree dream alive
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe
Shamini Bundell

item.title: Super hot plasma made easy with stabilising fibres
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03776-y

Carbon fibre blocks could make it easier to create uniform high temperature plasma for manufacturing and research.
item.dc:title: Super hot plasma made easy with stabilising fibres
item.dc:creator: Shamini Bundell

item.title: Karen Kaplan (1959–2023)
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03772-2

Karen Kaplan (1959–2023)
item.dc:title: Karen Kaplan (1959–2023)

item.title: A stable atmospheric-pressure plasma for extreme-temperature synthesis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06694-1

A plasma set-up consisting of a pair of carbon-fibre-tip-enhanced electrodes enables the generation of a uniform, ultra-high temperature and stable plasma (up to 8,000  K) at atmospheric pressure using a combination of vertically oriented long and short carbon fibres.
item.dc:title: A stable atmospheric-pressure plasma for extreme-temperature synthesis
item.dc:creator: Hua Xie
Ning Liu
Qian Zhang

Liangbing Hu

item.title: MSL2 ensures biallelic gene expression in mammals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06781-3

After loss of MSL2, a class of dosage-sensitive genes transitions from biallelic to monoallelic expression, whereby one allele remains active, retaining active histone modifications and transcription factor binding, and the other allele is silenced, exhibiting loss of promoter–enhancer contacts and the acquisition of DNA methylation.
item.dc:title: MSL2 ensures biallelic gene expression in mammals
item.dc:creator: Yidan Sun
Meike Wiese
Raed Hmadi
Remzi Karayol
Janine Seyfferth
Juan Alfonso Martinez Greene

item.title: An autonomous laboratory for the accelerated synthesis of novel materials
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06734-w

An autonomous laboratory, the A-Lab, is presented that combines computations, literature data, machine learning and active learning, which discovered and synthesized 41 novel compounds from a set of 58 targets after 17 days of operation.
item.dc:title: An autonomous laboratory for the accelerated synthesis of novel materials
item.dc:creator: Nathan J. Szymanski
Bernardus Rendy
Yuxing Fei

item.title: On-surface synthesis of aromatic cyclo[10]carbon and cyclo[14]carbon
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06741-x

We provide a modified strategy for the on-surface synthesis of cyclocarbons with 10 or 14 carbon atoms that provides a route for characterizing annular carbon allotropes.
item.dc:title: On-surface synthesis of aromatic cyclo[10]carbon and cyclo[14]carbon
item.dc:creator: Luye Sun
Wei Zheng
Wenze Gao
Faming Kang
Mali Zhao
Wei Xu

item.title: FOXP3 recognizes microsatellites and bridges DNA through multimerization
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06793-z

FOXP3 uses the forkhead domain to form a higher-order multimer after binding to TnG repeat microsatellites.
item.dc:title: FOXP3 recognizes microsatellites and bridges DNA through multimerization
item.dc:creator: Wenxiang Zhang
Fangwei Leng
Xi Wang
Ricardo N. Ramirez
Jinseok Park
Christophe Benoist
Sun Hur

item.title: Identification of constrained sequence elements across 239 primate genomes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06798-8

Whole-genome alignment of 239 primate species reveals noncoding regulatory elements that are under selective constraint in primates but not in other placental mammals, that are enriched for variants that affect human gene expression and complex traits in diseases.
item.dc:title: Identification of constrained sequence elements across 239 primate genomes

item.title: A resonant sextuplet of sub-Neptunes transiting the bright star HD 110067
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06692-3

Observations of six transiting planets around the bright nearby star HD 110067 show that they follow a chain of resonant orbits, with three of the planets inferring the presence of large hydrogen-dominated atmospheres.
item.dc:title: A resonant sextuplet of sub-Neptunes transiting the bright star HD 110067

item.title: Landscape dynamics and the Phanerozoic diversification of the biosphere
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06777-z

A model of sediment flux from the land to the oceans over the Phanerozoic eon explains differences in the fossil records of marine animal genera and land plant genera.
item.dc:title: Landscape dynamics and the Phanerozoic diversification of the biosphere
item.dc:creator: Tristan Salles
Laurent Husson
Manon Lorcery
Beatriz Hadler Boggiani

item.title: Exploring large-scale entanglement in quantum simulation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06768-0

On a 51-ion quantum simulator, we investigate locality of entanglement Hamiltonians for a Heisenberg chain, demonstrating Bisognano–Wichmann predictions of quantum field theory applied to lattice many-body systems, and observe the transition from area- to volume-law scaling of entanglement entropies.
item.dc:title: Exploring large-scale entanglement in quantum simulation
item.dc:creator: Manoj K. Joshi
Christian Kokail
Rick van Bijnen
Florian Kranzl
Torsten V. Zache
Rainer Blatt
Christian F. Roos
Peter Zoller

item.title: Associative pyridinium electrolytes for air-tolerant redox flow batteries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06664-7

The redox behaviour of pyridinium electrolytes under representative flow battery conditions is investigated, offering insights into air tolerance of batteries containing these electrolytes while providing a universal physico-chemical descriptor of their reversibility.
item.dc:title: Associative pyridinium electrolytes for air-tolerant redox flow batteries
item.dc:creator: Mark E. Carrington
Kamil Sokołowski
Erlendur Jónsson
Evan Wenbo Zhao
Anton M. Graf
Israel Temprano
Jade A. McCune
Clare P. Grey
Oren A. Scherman

item.title: The genetic legacy of the expansion of Bantu-speaking peoples in Africa
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06770-6

We gathered genetic data for 1,763 individuals from 147 populations across 14 African countries, and 12 Late Iron Age individuals, to trace the expansion of Bantu-speaking peoples over the past 6,000 years.
item.dc:title: The genetic legacy of the expansion of Bantu-speaking peoples in Africa
item.dc:creator: Cesar A. Fortes-Lima

item.title: Ending extreme poverty has a negligible impact on global greenhouse gas emissions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06679-0

Global emissions associated with the economic growth needed to alleviate extreme poverty are limited.
item.dc:title: Ending extreme poverty has a negligible impact on global greenhouse gas emissions
item.dc:creator: Philip Wollburg
Stephane Hallegatte
Daniel Gerszon Mahler

item.title: Scaling deep learning for materials discovery
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06735-9

A protocol using large-scale training of graph networks enables high-throughput discovery of novel stable structures and led to the identification of 2.2 million crystal structures, of which 381,000 are newly discovered stable materials.
item.dc:title: Scaling deep learning for materials discovery
item.dc:creator: Amil Merchant
Simon Batzner
Samuel S. Schoenholz
Muratahan Aykol
Gowoon Cheon
Ekin Dogus Cubuk

item.title: Pesticide use negatively affects bumble bees across European landscapes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06773-3

Results from 316 Bombus terrestris colonies at 106 agricultural sites across eight European countries find pesticides in bumble bee pollen to be associated with reduced colony performance, especially in areas of intensive agriculture.
item.dc:title: Pesticide use negatively affects bumble bees across European landscapes
item.dc:creator: Charlie C. Nicholson
Jessica Knapp

item.title: mRNA reading frame maintenance during eukaryotic ribosome translocation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06780-4

The accuracy of eukaryotic ribosome translocation relies on eukaryote-specific elements of the 80S ribosome, elongation factor 2 and transfer RNAs, all of which contribute to the maintenance of the messenger RNA reading frame.
item.dc:title: mRNA reading frame maintenance during eukaryotic ribosome translocation
item.dc:creator: Nemanja Milicevic
Lasse Jenner
Alexander Myasnikov
Marat Yusupov
Gulnara Yusupova

item.title: Human mobility networks reveal increased segregation in large cities
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06757-3

There is extreme socioeconomic segregation in large US cities, arising from a greater choice of differentiated spaces targeted to specific socioeconomic groups, which can be countered by positioning city hubs (such as shopping centres) to bridge diverse neighbourhoods.
item.dc:title: Human mobility networks reveal increased segregation in large cities
item.dc:creator: Hamed Nilforoshan
Wenli Looi
Emma Pierson
Blanca Villanueva
Nic Fishman
Yiling Chen
John Sholar
Beth Redbird
David Grusky
Jure Leskovec

item.title: Evidence for chiral supercurrent in quantum Hall Josephson junctions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06764-4

Ultra-narrow quantum Hall Josephson junctions defined in encapsulated graphene nanoribbons exhibit a chiral supercurrent, visible up to 8  T.
item.dc:title: Evidence for chiral supercurrent in quantum Hall Josephson junctions
item.dc:creator: Hadrien Vignaud

Benjamin Sacépé

item.title: Disease-specific tau filaments assemble via polymorphic intermediates
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06788-w

A time-resolved cryogenic electron microscopy analysis provides structural information on the processes of primary and secondary nucleation of tau amyloid formation, with implications for the development of new therapies.
item.dc:title: Disease-specific tau filaments assemble via polymorphic intermediates
item.dc:creator: Sofia Lövestam

Sjors H. W. Scheres

item.title: Cascaded compression of size distribution of nanopores in monolayer graphene
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06689-y

Cascaded compression, in which nanopores are compressed by cycles of shrinkage and expansion, is described, leading tohigh-density nanopores in monolayer graphene with a narrow pore-size distribution, left skewness and ultrasmall tail deviation.
item.dc:title: Cascaded compression of size distribution of nanopores in monolayer graphene
item.dc:creator: Jiangtao Wang

item.title: A probable Keplerian disk feeding an optically revealed massive young star
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06790-2

The authors suggest that a probable Keplerian disk is feeding an optically revealed massive young stellar object in the Large Magellanic Cloud.
item.dc:title: A probable Keplerian disk feeding an optically revealed massive young star
item.dc:creator: Anna F. McLeod
Pamela D. Klaassen
Megan Reiter
Jonathan Henshaw
Rolf Kuiper
